chapter_title: DISDAIN THINGS YOU CANNOT HAVE: IGNORING THEM IS THE BEST REVENGE
summary: In this chapter, Robert Greene explains that paying attention to what we cannot have only grants those things or individuals more power over us. Acknowledging an enemy or a problem can strengthen their position and highlight our weaknesses. By showing contempt or disdain, instead of engaging, we assert our superiority and diminish their importance. The chapter provides historical examples, including the failed Punitive Expedition against Pancho Villa, to illustrate the dangers of overcommitting to lost causes. Ultimately, silence and indifference often serve as the most profound forms of power and revenge.

slides.section_body: Acknowledging a problem can give it more power. The act of paying attention often inflates the significance of an enemy. Instead of confronting weaknesses head-on, ignoring them diminishes their importance.
slides.quote: To overlook a problem is to render it powerless.

slides.section_body: The Punitive Expedition against Pancho Villa shows how America underestimated him. Their attempts to contain him only fueled his fame and popularity, demonstrating the folly of direct confrontation.
slides.quote: Ignoring an adversary can sometimes elevate their stature.

slides.section_body: When faced with unattainable goals, pretending indifference minimizes feelings of defeat. Accepting what cannot be had with disdain is a more powerful response than visible desire.
Displaying contempt shows you can walk away from what you can't have. This strategy can unsettle others who seek your attention and create an aura of superiority around you.
slides.quote: Contempt is the prerogative of the powerful.

slides.section_body: Tangible attention to an enemy often backfires, giving them the upper hand. Microscopically scrutinizing the unworthy can amplify their presence and importance in our lives.
slides.quote: Engagement can be a downfall; indifference is true power.

slides.section_body: Great leaders have often ignored rising threats until it was too late. The failure to recognize potential rivals in their infancy can result in unforeseen dangers later.
slides.quote: Monitor quietly, but let most irritants pass unseen.

slides.section_body: Desire can be paradoxical; chasing what we want often leads to failure. By showing contempt, we shift the dynamic to our favor, enticing others to pursue us instead.
slides.quote: What you chase often eludes you; turn your back to attract.

slides.section_body: Creating a persona of indifference lets others know your time is valuable. Maintaining this distance consolidates respect and admiration, compelling others to seek your approval.
slides.quote: Your aloofness is as much an asset as your engagement.

slides.section_body: Contempt can play out as psychological warfare against an adversary. By sidelining others, we unsettle them, forcing them to react to our terms and elevating our standing.
slides.quote: Withholding attention is the ultimate power move.

slides.section_body: It's crucial to know when to engage and when to ignore. Understanding the distinction between trivial annoyances and genuine threats is vital for maintaining power.
slides.quote: Balance disdain with awareness; not all irritants are harmless.
